title: 108_hr5220
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Washington National Opera Commemorative Coin Act of 2004". The Washington National Opera, established in 1956, was designated the "National Opera" in 2000 by an Act of Congress. It provides educational programs for students of all ages, promotes public awareness and appreciation for opera, and supports gifted young American artists. Coins commemorating the 20th anniversary of the Washington National Opera Education and Community Programs will be authorized to aid in the education of students and promote awareness and appreciation for opera. The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue $1 coins with specific specifications, including weight, diameter, and composition. These coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items. The design of coins minted under this Act will represent the Washington National Opera and include inscriptions of value, year, and words like "Liberty" and "In God We Trust". The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Board of Directors of the Washington National Opera, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The design of coins minted under this Act will represent the Washington National Opera and include inscriptions of value, year, "Liberty," and "In God We Trust." The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with the Commission of Fine Arts and the Board of Directors of the Washington National Opera, and reviewed by the Citizens Coinage Advisory Committee. The issuance of coins under this Act will feature a design representing the Washington National Opera, with inscriptions of value, year, "Liberty," and "In God We Trust." The design will be chosen by the Secretary in consultation with relevant committees. Coins minted under this Act will be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at a single United States Mint facility. The Secretary may start issuing these coins from January 1, 2010, with sales possible before that date. Minting of these coins will cease after December 31, 2010, and they will be the first commemorative coins with the year "2010" inscribed on them. The Secretary will consult with the Board for promotion and marketing of these coins. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will receive a reasonable discount as well. Surcharges will also be applied to the coins. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

All sales of coins under this Act shall include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be promptly paid to the Board for the Washington National Opera Education and Community Program to support student education, opera awareness, and learning standards. The Board and the Program will be audited as required by law.
